Definition: In this task, you receive a public comment from online platforms. It is expected that you divide the comment into two classes: disagree and agree. Classify the comment as disagree if it expresses strong disagreement. Classify the comment as agree if no strong disagreement is expressed.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Weak and pathetic border enforcement.  Why bother with a border if this defines our Country.  Canada has become a pathetic weakling, likes its ruling party.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment expresses its strong disagreement with Canada.

Comment: The 'value proposition' of the media, in business terms, is as a broker of peoples' attention to advertisers. That invokes two potential incompatibilities. 
The first incompatibility is inherent to brokerage roles and is a subject given a lot of study in economic theory. The question boils down to this: how cheap can the media be in getting public attention and still provide the quantity and quality of attention the advertisers want. 
Note that the 'customers' are the advertisers, with their money dwarfing any subscription payments from the audience by a very large factor. That makes us, the readers/viewers, the 'product'. 
In the field of entertainment, this is a reasonably happy, cooperative arrangement. 
[Part 2 in replies...]

Comment: It is amazing how so many misunderstand the supremacy clause and state's rights. 

Supremacy clause- state may not prevent the Feds from enforcing federal law. 

States Rights- the Feds can not make states enforce federal law. 

What these councilmen did: they made a statement in which they don't agree with the way the Feds are doing business. What they didn't do: they didn't make any law preventing the state or the Feds from enforcing federal or state law. 

So where is the basis for a recall? There's not. No laws were broken. The Feds are still able to enforce federal law. The state is still able to enforce state law. In fact the city can still help both state and Feds. It was nothing more than a written opinion. Recall in Alaska is unlawful without a law being broken. 

this is nothing more than partisan politics, with no basis for Rule of Law!

Complex issue, no easy answers.

Comment: Wow. From  a history buff's perspective ... this is what happened in the run up to the Civil War. People had finally reached a point where they could no longer ignore each other's positions and were unwilling to love each other despite differing viewpoints. Interestingly, at that time, it wasn't slavery that was the topic splitting families so much as it was a) the crushing tariffs the North wanted to impose upon the South and 2) the election of a president (Lincoln) who had signaled his willingness to use the power of the executive to crush those he disagreed with.

Yeah, I know, that's not the popular re-interpretation of who Lincoln was, but that's how his opponents viewed him ... which I find interesting because we're in a very similar political situation now. If you hate Trump you think he's a tyrant who is going to crush you. If you like Trump you believe he's going to bring needed reform.

Which is true? I voted 3rd party, so I don't have a dog in this fight.

No healthcare plan is perfect however, but it was 100% better than what I had when I was growing up -which was 0 healthcare.

Comment: This is a bunch of BS by the DA's office in my opinion.  Judge Mooney is a very conservative person although liberal on social issues. Comment: For those who think the NHL is all 'bout Your Leafs, FYI:  Car 7-0-3 last 10, 79 pts, 5 behind Bos, 2 games in hand.  Car plays Det @ home back-to-back Mon/Tues.  Unlikely, but if they sweep, look out.

The NHL is, common sense says, messed up with how it awards pts in the standings.  Some games are worth 3 pts, others 2.  That is unfair.  There are different ways to arrange it, but all games must carry the same weight; otherwise it's slanted and cannot be justified.

If you want the 3 pt system, fine.  A win in reg is then worth 3 pts to the winning team.  Under that set-up, Bos is 4 pts clear of Your Leafs.

If you wanna go 2 pts, then Bos is only 1 pt up.  Your Leafs have 1 game in hand.

There is no justification for awarding 2 pts to a team that was 5-0 in reg, and awarding 2 pts again to a team that wins 4-3 in a 12-round SO.  Flawed.

Comment: The point was that the Sun has not/is not contributing to the warming of the last half century.

Much of the warming/cooling in paleoclimate was the result of very slow orbital variations of the Earth, and changes in CO₂. Those cycles mostly occurred on time scales not relevant to humans. Current warming is happening at the rate of about one order of magnitude greater than natural orbit/insolation warming.

Comment: What a thoughtless article, and it invites readers to be as unthinking as the writer. Reverse discrimination isn't real? That is logically absurd. In particular, it's preposterous to think that you can set gender equity quotas in professions women disdain - like technology and hard sciences, and not  have to discriminate in order to achieve balance.  We've seen this in numerous cases where less capable women or minorities are hired over more capable men or white people. We see it in Trudeau's cabinet. We used to see it when municipalities graded those who tested for positions on the police and fire service, and they would yank women and minorities who passed watered down tests from a list two hundred places down over men who did much better. This article is a cry to ignore merit, and to ignore equality of opportunity in favour of equality of results.  It is the call of the politically correct who ignore reality in favour of ideology and brainless ivory tower theories.

Comment: Maybe I just have had insanely good luck. And I'm sure a lot depends on where you are. But at three different locations I've had GCI internet service since 2005 (Anchorage, Palmer, and then Wasilla) I have nearly always got the advertised speeds. I do regular tests on my 100 mbps connection these days and consistently get sustained 100 mbps +/- 1 mbps at speedtest.net. 

"Laughably" small bandwidth caps start at 50 GB/month and go all the way up to 1 TB/month, on par with what you'd get in the lower 48., albeit at probably twice the price for the same bandwidth.

As for slowing down to dial-up speeds, not true. They will slow you to 768 kbps after you reach the cap. Dial-up tops out at 56kbps, so that is still 13x faster and not a bad connection for basic internet surfing.

Comment: Attorney General Jeff Session’s impassioned denial that he was colluding with Russia during the 2016 campaign was the most memorable quote from Tuesday’s Senate Intelligence Committee hearing. But if Senate Democrats seeking to bait and interrogate him weren’t particularly interested in his profession of innocence, it was hardly surprising. As was made plain by their questioning of former FBI director James Comey and the three intelligence chiefs last week, Democrats have moved the goalposts on the Russia investigation. They’ve all but given up on their quest to prove the Trump campaign colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 election — the charge at the heart of the ongoing congressional investigations. They are now solely focused on pinning a charge on President Trump and ultimately forcing him from office. With the collapse of the collusion narrative, they’ve seized upon “obstruction of justice” as the accusation that will, they hope, get Trump impeached

Comment: No one is proposing to make it illegal. The point is respect. Charges of cultural appropriation come up only when someone has misrepresentative themselves as belonging to another cultural, or has used offensive stereotypes, or has taken advantage of an existing discrimination.

It's just interesting how many White writers want to add People of Colour or Indigenous People to their stories to spice them up. If they're there just to show a representative cross-section of society, fine. If their otherness is of integral importance to the story, fine but get them right. If they're there to titillate, that's not fine.

Like the Bechdel test, one can ask a number of question as to why characters from another culture are there and if it's fair usage. But we know now that Blackface is never okay. We know cheap racist and sexist stereotypes are never okay. Shrugging and saying it's only fiction isn't an excuse. Words matter.

Comment: Payment methods bring about improvement in sustainable healthcare systems. The Canadian model of healthcare is not one of them. No other health system in the Western world is government-run. Pretending that a change in payment methods will resolve problems (including medical errors) is disingenuous.

To invoke lack of accountability is equally disingenuous: government-run systems are by definition non-transparent. In Canada, this is aggravated by substandard health information systems infrastructure (BC admitted a breach of their pharmaceutical information system no later than this week).

Changing payment methods will not improve:
- Decrepit infrastructure
- Substandard and insufficient equipment
- Inexperienced personnel (how do you acquire experience when you don't practice due to rationing?)
- Merry-go-round walk-in clinics where no one is accountable for services
- Inappropriate and untimely diagnoses and treatments

It is high time for Canadians to be told the truth

Comment: In reality, beefing up security at selected sites only results in shifting the threat to other more vulnerable targets where people congregate.  If it's not within an airport secured zone or a concert venue or school, then it will be at a popular supermarket, eatery, passenger bus, train, or retail store.  In a more-or-less free society you cannot install x-ray scanners or erect barbed wire barriers and electrified fences around everything.  Neither can most places afford round the clock security for the long haul, and even if one could afford it, it's the rare security setup relying on human beings that isn't eventually compromised by sheer boredom and fatigue.

So what does the average John and Jane Doe do about it?  Just expect to be involved in a mass emergency someday.  "This can't be happening to me!" is not a mindset conducive to survival.

Comment: When I first lived in Alaska in the 1970's I heard stories of the horror of the change from being a Russian Territory to an American Territory in 1868. The Russians from their capitol of Sitka had created through decades a form of law and order in the territory. Russian ships were making new and longer trade routes to the south. The Russians went on planning despite the politics.  In 1868 with the AK Purchase The Russians were given a choice to stay or go back. Many of the Russians who did stayed later scrambled to leave as law and order ended. The territory was now in total chaos. Mobs and gangs ruled and many innocent people died at their hands. Law came to the territory finally when the representatives in the AK territory pled their case to the US Congress and Union troops from the territory of WA state were sent to restore law and order. I asked why a Union Soldier from the Civil War era was buried in Alaska and that is what I was told.

Comment: You are so right. However it is very human to resist change, and most of us do in some aspect(s) of our lives. I recall in the late 90s our parish made the change to the priest facing the congregation and to the modern English translation - both of which had been resisted for years, mainly by the clergy. The priest suggested that we try it, for just 9 months (a good gestation period?) - at the end of that time we, the congregation, would discuss it and have a vote. In the meantime, he taught into the changes each week, paragraph by paragraph. It is the first time the majority had experienced the 'new' liturgy regularly. At the end of 9 mths the majority were overwhelmingly in favour of the new and did not want to revert. There were of course a few who still did not like it, but even they - out of love for the others - agreed and the new liturgy was accepted. For the sake of the few, every 5th Sunday in the month we reverted to the 'old' service. In the end no-one wanted it.

Comment: Answer to first paragraph: NO.

A lay person who can celebrate Mass is an oxymoron.  A lay person who can celebrate Confession, Anointing of the Sick, and Confirmation is an oxymoron.  The ability to celebrate these sacraments by definition, presupposes the valid reception of the Ministerial Priesthood.  

By definition, a priest is a lay person who has received the Sacrament of Holy Orders.  AS such, they are no longer lay.  A lay priest makes as much sense as a lay deacon or a lay bishop.  There is no such thing.

The Sacraments of Baptism and Marriage can be celebrated by a lay person in theory, but not the other Sacraments.

Comment: If you extend your oil change intervals to 25,000 km and abuse your engine beyond belief by only driving short distances in cold weather you might shorten the engine life enough to have a detectable failure before the car dies of old age.  Otherwise, the rest of the car will die long before the engine.  Modern engines with modern oil are getting oil changes far too often.  If stretch one oil change, in this case by 10%, the odds of doing any detectable harm to the engine are zero.  If you only ever do every second recommended change, your engine will still outlast the car.  Oil changes are only for the benefit of the next owner in any event.  My truck has 410,000 hard km on it, and as you can probably guess - not maintained to any kind of a schedule, and still has never had to have a litre of oil added between changes.  Its now been overheated twice due to a radiator incident and still shows no signs of any damage or wear or drivability.

Comment: Canadians need to re-think home-ownership...

It's often cheaper to rent, especially when you factor in opportunity costs. Also, many home-owners buy houses "to grow into" while renters tend to rent only what they need. And renting is more flexible, allowing people more freedom to chase job opportunities or adjust their housing to suit changes in their family and financial situations.

Renting is also low-risk. When the U.S. housing bubble burst in 2008, many U.S. home-owners were trapped "under-water". And now many Canadian home-owners could be trapped with increased mortgage payments. Sure, some people have made money off their house, but just as money people have lost their shirts because of home-ownership.

Comment: Nobody - because I said nothing about ideas being tolerable. I spoke of ideas being tolerANT or not. And that is an extremely easy thing to determine. Your idea is tolerant if, and only if, part of that idea is that you have to tolerate me and my ideas. It's a very simple quod-pro-quo calculation. I must tolerate your views even if I disagree with them - as long as you do the same for me. If your view is that I should be cut into tiny little pieces and fed to the dogs, I'm not obligated to tolerate that view. If your view is that I should not be allowed to express my views - then I'm not obligated to tolerate that view and I am justified to prevent you expressing it so that all the many other views can remain safe to express.

Comment: I'm not sure if this article is clear in the language around duties. And therefore I'm not sure at what point in the schedule (see below) that the US wants to increase to $800.00 as it's currently at $800.00 after 48 hours or more:
Returning to Canada from the US after less than 24 hours: No personal exemptions on duty to be paid.
Returning after 24 and 48 hours: $200.00 without paying any duties or taxes.

Returning after 7 days: $800.00 again but this time the goods can follow you to Canada later than when you arrive back in Canada.

Comment: The temperature difference to 120 years ago is unknown, since there simply aren't enough data. Likewise, the temperature difference between now and the last ice age isn't known precisely; there are lots of unverifiable assumptions that go into the calculation of temperatures from ice or sediment isotope ratios. For what it it worth, the most direct estimates I am aware of are based on rates of aspartic acid racemization in fossil bones found in East Africa and close to Mediterranean. If those estimates are correct - 4 to 6 degrees - then the temperature difference was most likely higher at the poles. 

Yes, CO2 does cause warming, but it is obvious to anyone not willfully blind that the rate of warming is much lower than in the model-based disaster scenarios that were popularized by Hansen. Moreover, there is no evidence whatsoever of negative consequences of this moderate warming. The hysteria is unfounded.

Comment: kag - who is to pay if they get sick, if anyone gets sick with a life threatening illness?  the point of insurance is the spread the risk.  If we spread the risk among all people, then the average any one pays is no more than the fair share of all the expenses.  In other words, rather than one person being financially ruined by ill health - the point of insurance - the cost is spread among everyone.  Break this down into smaller groups and the risk of catastrophic costs hitting someone in that group rises; when that happens that groups premiums skyrocket.  More, put "healthy" people in one group and "unhealthy" people in another group, and it is a foregone conclusion which group will have higher expenses.  

By the way, I am also on Medicare and find it good.  I do have a Medicare Supplement plan; I have to hope my finances hold up so I can keep it.  If I can't it would not take long for a serious illness to deplete the rest of my assets.

Comment: Art is correct to my knowledge - state governments MUST pass budgets in order to spend, and technically I think they must even pass BALANCED budgets; they cannot deficit spend.  The Federal government, by issuing Treasury securities, does two things:  1) Funds it's operations when spending exceeds receipts + accumulated funding; and 2) provides citizens and most particularly the Social Security fund with a relatively safe, modest-return investment option.  States, while they can issue debt, don't really have the same powers in that regard as the Federal government.  And it makes sense really - would you buy bonds issued by a state to cover that state's current operating expenses?  I wouldn't, that indicates the state is in dire financial condition.  That's why I find the issuance of debt to cover state pension obligations so scary.  It may be necessary given the magnitude of the problem, but it is very much kicking the can down the road.

As a high school student in the late 80s, I remember being called into the office to be told that I was the only girl signed up for drafting class, and did I want to reconsider my choice?  Intimidated, I transferred to typing.  I recall in grad school, the students being groomed for advancement to top academia positions were male.  Neil Degrasse Tyson wonderfully explains his experience of teachers repeatedly encouraging him to pursue sports rather than science. Comment: Automated leak detection systems have been problematic for decades. And when they do work and send an alarm signal, there are known cases where monitoring personnel have ignored or bypassed the alarms because they made a judgement call to consider them as nuisance alarms.

This is one area where the industry must be made to pay up for a concerted effort to have an industry standard leak detection model developed, tested and adopted.

But, in the meantime, why not hire personnel, possibly with sniffer dogs, to manually patrol at least waterway crossings. I can absolutely say, from experience,  that the industry has fallen in love with automated systems even when those systems are ineffective AND more expensive than an old fashioned approach.

This Saskatchewan spill was not catastrophic. It was not minor either.  200 cubic meters of oil (about 1200 barrels) is far, far above any threshold where it should have gone undetected for more than a few hours.

Comment: It appears based on the comments in this article that a royal commission was the wrong approach for what the advocates wanted to achieve. Royal commissions by their nature follow a very traditional and somewhat narrow approach. The only royal commission that strayed from that approach that I am aware of was the Berger Commission on the Mackenzie Pipeline proposal in the 1970's.  Berger went and visited the villages and communities that would be impacted.
With regard to opening old cases, I believe that would have put the commission on shaky legal ground. I am sure some more knowledgeable people can add to this but I believe the Supreme Court ruling on the inquiry  into the Westray mining disaster established a precedent on the limitations on inquiries and how far they can delve into specific legal issues that could still be ruled within the courts.
It may have been better for the Minister of Justice or the Minister of Public Safety and Security order a detailed case review process.

Comment: Excellent insight Anchor.   It is very unlikely that a sudden wealth scenario will turn out well without some luck, the most important "luck" being that the people involved have real, personal support coming to them to help them see through the fog.  Smart people who have been heads down and suddenly find themselves in a position of liquidity are at real risk.  Advice ranges from strong to destructive and people in these situations typically don't get a second chance - they have monetized their life's work or received some other type of windfall proceeds.  They have to get it right and the first part of getting it right is keeping it and protecting it for the long term.  I've built a lifetime of discipline to manage our own wealth and trust me, it really has taken a lifetime.  We made every mistake there is to make but made them early and on the way, giving us time to recover.  We are now in a very strong position to filter advice and give some of our own.

Comment: I agree. Even for those of us not in Alberta, it's true that slowing Canadian oil production will be tough. Nobody's disputing the economic benefits that oil and gas provide for Alberta and for the rest of Canada with regards to deficit-reduction. But at this point, I feel like trying to keep hydrocarbon-based fuels afloat is like trying to subsidize the telegraph. And it's not as if transitioning doesn't have benefits: in Ontario, we completely phased out coal power, and we haven't had a smog alert in the past two years. Canada is unique in that it's one of the world's few net exporters of energy. We have the potential to become a real powerhouse as we move onto the Green Age, but only if we embrace change. As a nation we already produce 80% of our energy from clean sources and renewables: that's an amazing place to start.

Comment: The lack of liquidity is a domestic problem.

Boomers are sitting on trillions (across Canada) in tax free capital gains on real estate, in many cases (esp. Vancouver) more money than they made working for their whole lives.  Hence, they are holding onto these properties and refuse to leave them unless it's feet first.  This kills liquidity and makes it a sellers market.  Toss in foreign buyers looking to park money and the overall pricing soars.

We have to cap the primary residence cap gains exemption to $250K.  This exemption was to help young families (boomers at the time) upsize their homes as their families grew, not to create tax free millionaires in nursing homes.

By tossing in this cap, boomers would start cashing out to avoid the taxes, make way for the next two generations that follow them and maybe it would become somewhat affordable to have a kid in Canada again.

Comment: It's a good thing Shakespeare wrote hundreds of years ago rather than in the modern era. He had a penchant for setting his works in and drawing his characters from foreign locales, particularly Italy. The reasons for this have been debated. Some believe he was simply reflecting the public fascination in England at the time for Italian culture. Others believe that Shakespeare was inspired by the works of the great Roman historian Tacitus.  Whatever the case, Shakespeare didn't speak Italian and it's unlikely he ever set foot in Italy. Does this diminish the credibility and/or impact of his work? Does it render him an appropriator? Shakespeare would no doubt be utterly mystified by the modern debate about cultural appropriation. In his defense, many would surely note that great art is universal in both inspiration and appeal.

Comment: I don't think retro-fitting is really much of a cost driver (assuming your house even has good candidate roof exposure and angle).  

If you're talking about a house being pre-wired to handle a solar installation, you still pay for that whether it's a retrofit or is in the purchase price of the house.  Either way, you pay for it.  

The bigger obstacle is that it really doesn't tend to save any money to install rooftop solar.  I have a good candidate house configuration for it, but even with the big tax credits (an issue in itself), it just doesn't calculate out to any savings for 20-30 years.  And you lose the opportunity cost of that up-front capital, and have the added risk of damage or failure to deal with.  

Of course, no one knows exactly what utility rates will be in the future either, but they tend to remain pretty stable, especially since they're PUC controlled.  

I'm open to the idea, but it just doesn't make economic sense.

Comment: I don't think you understand how the money side of the news works. Read the piece before you comment on it. Newspapers are not suffering from declining readership. More people are reading the news now than ever before, since it's easy to get for free online. The revenue problems newspapers are suffering from are directly caused by declining sales of ADVERTISING. This is because the companies and individuals that used to buy newspaper ads are now buying Facebook and Google ads.  The cost of a newspaper subscription or single copy purchase has NEVER in the history of newspapers been enough to cover the expense of paying all the journalists, photographers and editors required to produce that paper. Those costs have ALWAYS been paid for with advertising sales. If every Canadian over the age of 12 had a newspaper subscription, the industry would still have a revenue problem.

"[You do understand] This principle is what makes the decisions in Colorado's Amendment 2 .... possible?"

Respectfully, sir, you are not only incorrect but incorrect by precisely 90 degrees. The Constitution expressly grants to Congress the power to enforce civil rights, and Congress has recognized that private conspiracies to deprive citizens of their rights are necessary, which Congress did ... in 1871! The Supreme Court has repeatedly endorsed this interpretation (even by conservatives while limiting an even broader scope). Private, non-gov't acts have repeatedly deprived people of their rights, hence the law.

Comment: I agree with your core points, but I think you overstate the economic impact of deportations when you speak of "collapse".  Estimates of the impact vary widely, but if Trump ends up deporting 2% to 3% of the working population over a period of time there is bound to be an economic impact.  Some estimates of the impact are quite mild if you assume that there are a few million Americans waiting to work for below-market wages, while the scarier estimates include a severe decline in home construction and a recession that exceeds the last one in 2008.

As a Canadian, I don't want to see mass deportations because every recession the US has impacts Canada as well, and we really don't need more economic challenges to deal with.

Comment: A welcome caution from Mr. Radwanski.

The CPC isn't just having "a moment" of vulnerability; they've been without coherent policies or a centre of gravity since the person who essentially created--and defined--them quit.

Stephen Harper ran the CPC pretty much as a dictatorship, and attracted followers with few viable policy ideas of their own to offer. Their main values to him were blind obedience and a talent for sneering at the opposition. The vacuum Harper left won't easily be filled--especially since  his approaches to policy and governing have already been rejected by voters.

What are the alternatives--to both Harper and his policies?

The party needs to be redefined, and that is what this leadership race is really about. It's not just about who will be crowned leader of a party with a long-established set of broadly attractive policies. They're starting almost from scratch, and just being opposed to the current government, as they are now, isn't enough to win them power.

Comment: Thanks Rob.  After years of investing for growth, with some success, a couple of years ago I decided to stop measuring my investing success by the size of my portfolio and instead measure it by the amount of annual dividends I'm earning.  I was concerned last year and strongly considered selling out in September and waiting for the 'crash'.  Subsequent events have proven that would not have been wise, and as I now move towards retirement this spring I have a healthy dividend portfolio of mostly Canadian Dividend All-Stars paying me more than I'll require in annual income to fund that retirement.  No more watching the ups and downs of the market.  I'm following the annual dividend increases that I expect to take care of inflation in the coming years.  People need to re-access how they measure their investing success, and not worry so much about short term gains and losses in stock values.

Comment: In Gallup polls since they started asking in 1944 until this election, only about 20% of the public has supported the current system of awarding all of a state's electoral votes to the candidate who receives the most votes in each separate state

Support for a national popular vote for President has been strong among Republicans, Democrats, and Independent voters, as well as every demographic group in every state surveyed. In the 41 red, blue, and purple states surveyed, overall support has been in the 67-81% range - in rural states, in small states, in Southern and border states, in big states, and in other states polled. 

Voters want to know, that no matter where they live their vote actually was equally counted and mattered to their candidate. Most Americans think it is wrong that the candidate with the most popular votes can lose. We don't allow this in any other election in our representative republic.

Comment: @Canoutchie: I think you make a valid point about the rationale for low rates. Low rates have also served to spike the value of all kinds of assets, enriching those who might otherwise be unable to cover the costs of their retirement (a big deal given our demographic bulge). (Note: no individual in a given generation is better or worse than an individual in any other generation.)

I don't expect rates to spike in a massive way. But I do think you might be over-estimating the willingness of subsequent generations to be economically thwarted.

In the next 5-10 years, the majority of boomers will have exited the work force. Their significant clout at the ballot box will remain, but policies (including approaches to interest rates) will also need to accommodate those who are working. Those regions that keep policy focused very heavily on the boomers will see younger people move away (other cities, provinces, or countries), decimating the taxbase and leading to a loss of essential skills.

Comment: One has to remember that publishing is a business. I've seen many a creative magazine come and go because they could not cash flow the opportunity. The magazine industry is changing - I believe titles like the Lucky Peach are exactly where magazine media is heading. 

Of course, if publishers are willing to give away their content online it will be hard to pay the bills. I can go to luckypeach.com and get all sorts of stories and recipes without paying for any of it. And with adblocking, I don't even have to see any ads. How is this a viable business model again? How do we pay our bills and hire creative writers and amazing graphic designers? One of the things I loved about Lucky Peach was their cover artwork, their photography, their font choices. Brilliant work.

Those who create a business model around unique/well-written content and also create a money making model to support it will succeed in the niche magazine marketplace. It's not art. It's a business.

Comment: You're right that the decline began in the 80's and 90's, however it was very gradual, and unremarkable. In the 80's and 90's anyone could achieve their dreams if they were motivated, the difference is that the unmotivated ones had a bit less disposable income.

My dad had no formal education and had no problem acquiring 3 houses in the late 80's through unskilled labour (in a major city).  By the late 80's he got cocky, opened a business, and quit his job, by the beginning of 1990 he was bankrupt.   In 1994 he went back to the exact same company and was annoyed his waged hasn't appreciated as much as he thought it should.  I graduated in 2002, I waited to go to university.  My friends that went to university immediately had a chance of getting good jobs.  When I graduated I was the person in my honors class that got a job in my field.. everyone else doubled down on more degrees (cont).

The US has fluoridated for over 70 years and nearly 3 out of 4 Americans on public water systems get the benefit. Most of the Western world has water or salt fluoridation, water with already enough fluoride or socialized medicine. Clallam County is a dental professional shortage area. Fluoridation has been gone for a year and the people who took it away have no replacement solution. To be fair, it's because there really isn't one as cost effective - fluoride in water costs about a dollar a year per family member - filling a single cavity costs over a hundred.

Sequim could be doing better. They have a pediatric dental clinic (unlike Port Angeles) that is always busy.

Comment: Lessons from the PAST only go so far.  Canada no longer has the work gangs, assembly lines and office pools that employed so many 'til the mid 1970s.  By the 1990s, outsourcing of manufacturing began, then sped up to be joined by outsourcing of jobs.  Add new technologies intersecting with materials' science, and we don't have a substantial domestic workforce anymore. We have a 'just in time' or gig economy.

Canada has dished out approximately a million 10-year temporary resident visas EACH year since 2010 when the program began: 940,214 such visas in the first year -- but NO requirement to file income taxes as temp residents.. Add 300,000 new immigrants ... plus refugees. House prices UP, UP -- 

Canada must identify what it can do best instead of selling out to other nations. Too often, politicians tried to pick and subsidize economic 'winners'. Result: debts & deficits at all level. Technological change is SO rapid .. governments are slow and home to self-serving politicians.

We did a 0% rollover in '03 then  in '04 made a 3%/yr, 3 year offer that the unions accepted for Class 2/3 then a 4 - 3 -3% offer to the Class Ones, which the interest arbitrators accepted. Militarily-speaking, the Syrian government has achieved a very important victory. It's possible that reprisals could follow, but on balance I think they won't. State of Alaska Department of Law:

Comment: There are many things that can make Mass more meaningful and prayerful; many that can distract from the experience; and a lot of room to disagree about which is which.
One of the post-Vatican II innovations that I appreciate less over the years is concelebration. I recognize that there are times when it's appropriate and meaningful. However, a priest-friend tells me that he rarely concelebrates, and never just because he doesn't have a scheduled Mass on a given day. Instead, he sits with the congregation and 'concelebrates' in the same way they do -- as a member of the priestly people of God.
For me, concelebrated Masses tend to emphasize what I regard as the church's single most important deficiency: the failure to ordain women. The more concelebrants, the more glaringly obvious is the lack of women. I suppose this is equally obvious at any and every Mass, but I notice it more at concelebrations.

Comment: East Polynesia colonized faster and more recently than previously thought
January 4, 2011 
The study was based on an analysis of the validity of more than 1,400 radiocarbon dates from 47 islands in the region collected from their own and other researchers' published studies.
Polynesian ancestors settled in Samoa around 800 B.C., then much later moved to colonize the region in two distinct phases—earliest in the central Society Islands between A.D. 1025 and 1120, four centuries later than previously assumed. Then, between 70 and 265 years later, dispersal continued in one major ‘pulse’ to all remaining islands including New Zealand, Hawai`i and Easter Island (Rapa Nui) between A.D. 1190 and 1290. The timing and sequence of this remarkable event has been highly debated and poorly resolved, precluding the understanding of cultural and ecological change that followed.

https://phys.org/news/2011-01-east-polynesia-colonized-faster-previously.html

Comment: Perhaps paradoxically, as the remaining fishermen switched to fishing crab and shrimp and other species, the landed value of the fishery went up considerably after the cod moratorium.  It's not that there is no future for the fishery after cod.

Fundamentally, it's more about a shift of technology and markets.  When people had to row out to catch fish in open dories, and bring it ashore to salt it, it took a lot of labour and the salted fish wasn't worth much money.  Now they've got big powerful boats and fancy gear, far fewer fishermen are needed to catch the same amount of fish, and they'll get more money for it if they can get market it fresh.  There will always be some outports where the economy is based on fishing, just no where near as many.

Comment: Development of doctrine, Assumption, is very much alive and well, and continues as always. You question, therefore, is very cogent. 

First, yes of course, Jesus is present in the Eucharist, and Jesus is God, and therefore the Eucharist is adorable.

Second, development of doctrine does not mean that every development is to be evaluated by the future as positive. As well as the Spirit guiding, the human element in development is very strong. Indeed the Evil One is very keen to get in on the act of development to lead us astray.

Given both of these, I would suggest that the Eucharist is preeminently sacred food as evidenced by the the manner in which it was introduced by Jesus. There are two reasons, IMHO, for today downplaying the Eucharist as an object of adoration: (1) it was introduced and served for a long time to displace frequent reception, and (2) emphatic adoration outside of mass is a uniquely Catholic practice. Eccumenism is a solid reason for down playing this practice.

Comment: Contractors pocket profits.  Taxpayers who approve bonds to construct buildings,  bridges,  roads,  etc.,  now pay non competitive,  set by the State,  wages on Davis Bacon projects in Oregon,  both for Federal and State projects.  The transfer of money is not from the public treasury to the contractor,  by passing labor.  Labor can negotiate and contractors can hire or have union contracts and labor,  or not.  The projects have public employee oversight as to methods,  materials,  processes.  Or so we are told.  So if there were a wage savings,  the public should expect more construction from their bonded indebtedness.  

Featherbedding went out with the railroad labor contracts 60 years ago.  But the Feds and States are stuck with Davis Bacon and Jones Act artificial wage rates set by union public employees.  It is a dishonest process in Oregon.  And why Avakian lost the Sec of State election.  He was a punisher,  not a  consensus builder.

Comment: Actually @Left of Right - in most restaurants now the tip does not go directly into your servers pocket.  Tips are withheld by management, and then pooled and distributed to staff at both the front and back of the house.

Your server may only see a couple of dollars of the $15 tip you added.

One Vancouver hotel I know of with mandatory gratuities for large groups,  keeps back a certain percentage for the "house" to pay labour costs. 

My kids - and their friends - have (some still are)  worked in the hospitality system. Some restaurants/bars are much better than others in how they treat their employees with respect to tipping out.     

This is  a reason why the industry is having challenges keeping staff for gratuity positions that were once coveted.... and why gratuities are now "an issue".  Bad management has taken over the tip jar, and staff are either relocating to a more fair employer,  or out of the industry.

Comment: Germany was indeed a founding member of the Euro. Not sure what your point is. 

The rate the final DM conversion was fixed at what was considered "strong" relative to the the other currencies, hence overvalued. In part that was because Kohl had set the Ostmark conversion rate too high during reunification, and impart because it was the strength of the DM that the other currencies were trying to adopt.

I admit I had forgotten the initial fall, and was thinking more of the post 2001 period, after Germany introduced the Hartz reforms. 

The rise from 2001 to the peak in 2008 completely blows the whole "Germany manipulates the Euro argument" out of the water, since Germany would have been seriously disadvantaged by that move; rather than grow exports the way you point out, they would have been crushed.

Comment: The report does not suggest that its conclusions are “hard science”. It explains at the beginning that if there are common threads in social science research, then those common threads are more likely to be reliable. Social science never has the reliability of “hard science” because the experiments cannot be repeated. But in ordering human affairs, we have to rely on something, as imperfect as it may be. On p 252 the report quotes the John Jay data that shows that after altar girls were introduced in 1983 “the offending rates against both altar boys and altar girls were approximately equal (Terry & Freilich 2012).” That would suggest that opportunity is a much more important factor than sexual orientation. There is a whole subchapter on the John Jay reports and its findings (which the authors do not dispute) that most abuse was with post pubescent boys. They do disagree with some other aspects of the John Jay Reports, but not the ones you mention.

Comment: My God, LoL, the person just died; his/her family is grieving; good memories are being shared; a Catholic funeral was sincerely wanted; pain and tears can be assuaged; and God--far above even the bishop's pay grade--has already made a judgment about the deceased's eternal soul.

The family just wants a funeral and an honest obituary. How trendy. 

But the bishop wants to do what all loving shepherds and compassionate pastors should do at a time like this--he wants to draw the line! So is it not the bishop who is using a family's grief and a dead person's good name to make a point? Hubris or the "Joy of Loving"?

Even after we die, it's the bishop who calls the shots? I hear God saying, "Hey, Morlino, that's MY call"? 

This is what happens when clericalism and legalism unite to rid the Church of ambiguity and confusion through Rulebook Religion.  

It's time for other bishops to challenge this rigid--yes, I said RIGID--enforcement that, in itself, gives scandal. Very public scandal.

Comment: not so fast you  Liberal Party apologists - yes our leaders can be impeached - it's a generic term referring to removal from office - how it's done is a matter of debate but is possible


almost happened in 2006 when harper was found in contempt

In theory the Prime Minister of Canada or anyone for that matter can be impeached by the House of Commons. The House of Commons retains the power of Impeachment, inherited from the British Parliament, because our constitution states that ours is "similar in principle" to the constitution of Britain…………It should be noted the last person to be impeached in Britain was Henry Dundas in 1806, so the practice has long since come into disuse. It would be very unconventional to say the least for the Canadian Parliament to dig up these old powers and use them, especially against the PM. But in theory it is possible. Though how the procedure would be amended in Canada would need to be negotiated.

Comment: Its funny that this article assumes either all-seasons (no-seasons) or winter tires.  If you want to maximize your traction and safety year-round, you should be switching between summer tires and winter tires.

The other critical point this article misses, is that by putting on snow tires for around half the year, you are doubling the life of your summer tires.  Since winter and summer tires cost a comparable amount of money, it means that the only net cost of using winter tires is for the extra set of rims and getting them changed.  The latter cost can be mitigated by changing them yourself (a half hour job if you have the right tools).

Comment: Susan, some of your points are well taken. Please be aware that comparing the single-track and the multi-use trails might be somewhat analogous to comparing bird watching in Denali National Park and in New York City. You do not expect to have the same experience. Similarly, cyclists on multi-use trails share them with dogs, both on and off leash, and kids, skateboarders and such. Cycling on single-track is a totally different experience where the trails are sometimes one-way to prevent injuries, to prevent some run-ins with others on the trails, and to prevent wear on the trails to become too much. Also, single-track trails are used almost exclusively for recreation. It is very rare that cyclists can use them for commuting or for access to other trails. Important, too, is that some of the multi-use trails are made inoperable by contractors trashing bridges to connect one part of a trail to another. That does not occur on single-track trails. Thanks for considering all perspectives.

Comment: This has been so for many decades.  Back in the 1970's countries to which Canada was not removing were referred to as "IS 26 countries" after the Immigration Manual reference that gave policy directions to Immigration officers.

Certain countries have been so designated over the years - a temporary suspension of removals (TSR) halts removals to a country but  it  is not permanent and is subject to changing conditions.  Iran, Iraq and China have been listed in the past and it was policy during the Cold War to not remove citizens of Soviet Bloc countries

Currently per s. 230 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, the Minister of Public Safety has the authority to impose, maintain or lift a TSR.  Often work and study permits are offered as special processing for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.

Here is the TSR for Haiti and Zimbabwe (now expired):
http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/resources/manuals/bulletins/2015/ob600.asp

Comment: Programming, as I'm sure you are aware, has changed enormously since the days of its infancy. In the 1950s, program sizes were measured in bytes and executed on punch cards. By the 1960s (at least the late 1960s) disc drives were available (small capacity, enormous cost) and program sizes had crept up into kilobytes. Program sizes for personal computers are now measured in gigabytes (I have no idea about mainframe program sizes).

I'm not a programmer and so can't go into more detail about the changes, but the sheer size of programs must surely make a difference to the type of intellect needed to deal with them.

Comment: Well. You told me. I'm suitably chastened. Look, pseudonymous one, in the reality TV world that brought Trump to White House, appearances ARE reality. Trump is impossible without his penchant for the spectacle. Many modern  rulers have discovered the legitimizing power of a well-managed spectacle. It's just that Trump has been doing it for three decades, longer than anyone in American public life, ever. Usually you have to be dead to be a mythical figure of power here. 

But this is not true of European monarchs. They WERE emissaries of the divine, legends in their own time, and the trappings of royalty--including all images of the King/Queen--were carefully managed to convey this. 

Melania, as was Marie Antoinette, is part of a carefully-structured spectacle of power by which Trump iterates his vision of  the nation, of "making America great again". It is necessary for someone to pay attention to these parallels. Melania IS our Queen Marie and her son's name is "Baron" . . .

Comment: What is a "Catholic hospital", anyway?  I'm a family physician with privileges at St Joseph's Hospital, the only acute care hospital in the Comox Valley on Vancouver Island.  It is a Catholic foundation.  It prohibits Medical Assistance in Dying on site.  Patients must be transferred home or to another hospital for MAiD.  The nearest one is 45 minutes away, so the whole transfer process takes a minimum of at least 2 hours.  Transfers of people so sick that they would not have been moved for any other reason have already happened.  

Only 12% of the Comox Valley declared itself Catholic in the last census.  The staff demographic is likely to be about the same.  Judging by the response of nursing staff in particular to press reports of the anti-MAiD policy, the majority are strongly opposed to the policy.  So is St Joseph's really a "Catholic hospital".  The Bishop of Victoria (the owner) and the Board say so.

A national poll showed 80% of Catholics support MAiD.

Comment: John,

While I thoroughly endorse and follow a dividend-focused strategy for any individual equities I own, your performance, benchmarking against the TSX total returns (5 year, 7.2%) is flawed when your initial portfolio initially had more than 24% in USD-denominated holdings.

Given the favourable impact in exchange rates over this period, I feel it is only fair to use a benchmark including S&P500 total-return (in CAD$) for the $12,239 of your $50K in Coca-Cola, Johnson & Johnson and P&G. Morningstar.com (the US site) yields a 19.34% total return through 9/27, a date pretty close to the end of the Strategy Lab closing date.

Doing the math, I calculate that the compounded 5-year total return of the benchmark works out to 10.17%, a value that is about 150 bps less than your portfolio.

I'm always on the watch for currency effects, decrying the Odlum Brown ads which benchmark against only the TSX when their model portfolio is about 50% in USD holdings. Apples & Oranges, indeed.

Comment: Stats show Victoria typicallyhad about 3.5% of real estate sales to offshore buyers; not just from China, but from all over the world.  Victoria is a university town, on the Pacific Rim with easy access to all of Asia.  Parents buy homes for their student children to live in. It is very common.

Since the 15% tax in Vancouver, the percentage of offshore buyers is said to be about 5.8%.  Simply put, the speculative types aren't interested in Victoria.  Their interest changed to Toronto, Seattle and 
San Fransisco; their focus is on major metropolitan areas. 

As a practical matter, the City of Victoria is one of 13 separate municipalities that make up greater Victoria.  Victoria proper has only 70,000 of the 350,000 souls.  How would granting a taxation right to Victoria work if it didn't apply in all other municipalities too?  And the other municipalities aren't governed by rabid socialists and unicorn herders . . . they aren't asking for the tax at all.

Comment: Why would someone "like" a comment that hasn't been seen, because it was removed prior to the "like" being given?  
I can think of a couple of reasons. 
One simply likes everything the removed author says; one is registering a "vote" against the comment to which the removed comment was reply, regardless of its content; one is hoping that the comment was actually uncivil (v. the vague and undefined incivility that occasionally causes some posts to be removed) against the interlocutor; one is seeking to curry favor; one hopes that others will believe the "like" was registered before the comment's removal.  Probably a number of others.
I'm not saying anything about your comment, BTW; I didn't see it.  I've had a comment dropped for no reason I can fathom.  Once re-posted, it stayed.  If that happened to you, by all means re-post it.

Comment: The 25K  limit was set for the "middle class" many years ago. You were deemed sufficient rich at over 100K in income that you could do any extra savings without tax assistance. There is no law prohibiting savings outside RRSPs. Even 25K / yr. over 30+ years at a reasonable rate of return will give you over a million. The problem with recent low interest rates is that even a "balanced" portfolio is not returning as much as expected. 

If you make RRSPs unlimited, you end up with the small business "problem" - those with excess cash will simply hide it away and defer all taxes. Government does want to collect income taxes, and small business owners have managed to defer taxes (except the low SB tax) for years. 

Finally, the SB can specifically set up an individual pension plan for retirement of the owner, but the previous system did not encourage that.

Comment: The same is true regarding all dopamine-deficiency ailments: ADHD, psychosis, schizophrenia, anxiety, depression, azlheimer's...
Dopamine is what a brain uses to connect information across synapses, and when it's lacking, information cannot be connected, and that is the premise of mental stress. When a person has dopamine-deficiency, the brain region that is most affected by it experiences some atrophy.
This isn't a big mystery: Dopamine is a brain's work-fuel, and since teenagers' brains are experiencing higher workload than average, they therefore require more dopamine than average to handle that workload. The strain on their dopamine availability is why teenagers are so susceptible to mental stress-related ailments, which are all dopamine-deficiency ailments.
Pure cocaine is one of the most effective and healthy ways to treat any dopamine-deficiency state.
Institutional medicine is a hoax, built on deliberate deception, and incompetent ignorance.

Comment: We can quibble about fuel costs.  You forgot maintenance and repairs. For my 2002 Honda Odyssey it was $11K and that doesn't include the $4k that I didn't spend when the transmission failed. (Honda settled a class action suit in the US which didn't help me.) For my 2000 BMW 323i, it was a whopping $30k before I finally gave up and towed it to the junk yard for the $3k EV Scrap-It rebate. So far, the LEAF costs~300/year for scheduled tire rotations and brake fluid flush. I expect to replace the LRR tires every 60K for another $3K.  I live at the top of a hill and chewed through brakes every 2 years. With regen, the LEAF is doing much better, say a brake job every 3 years for $1K. I can easily replace the battery out of maintenance savings. But there is absolutely no evidence that the battery will need replacement. I already accounted for capacity loss. When I lose 3 bars (27%), I'll still have 100 km range which covers my daily driving.  Of course, the Bolt will do much better.

Comment: While I agreed with TSHiggins' point, I do take umbrage with the obviously urban paradigm repeated here.
I grew up in rural Colorado and now live in the greater Denver area.  The urban areas are not wealthy and rural regions are not poor.  There are rich people, middle class and poor in both regions.  The richest person that I have ever known personally wore bib-overalls and drove a 20 year old pick-up while the poorest people I've ever come across (in the U.S.) have all lived in an urban city.

Rural areas are no different than urban areas when it comes to schools.  Some districts are willing to pay in the form of taxes and others aren't.  In the city of Aurora, there is a stark difference between Cherry Creek Schools and Aurora Schools.  In rural areas there are just a lot more that aren't willing to pay for it.  It's not that they can't, they choose not to.  But for all the talk of self-reliance and anti-state government, not a single one will turn down money from the state.

Comment: After decades of capital funding, and hundreds of millions of dollars poured into failed systems, ADEC has belated recognized that there was a problem. Good.

Unfortunately, this system seems to have the same flaws that have doomed other attempts at rural sanitation: complexity, high maintenance (related to complexity), and high cost, both the initial capital cost and the maintenance cost. The reason that many rural systems have not totally collapsed is that there is a system of state-funded Rural Maintenance Workers, highly-skilled mechanics stationed in rural hubs around the state. RMWs have rescued untold systems from failure and, particularly in the winter, from destruction. Given the state's fiscal situation, who knows how long the RMWs will continue to have jobs?

Elegant, complex, and expensive owner-maintained systems are simply not viable. Flush-haul may be the best we can do, but even that may be too expensive for many.

But good luck in your search.

Comment: "...enough time to practice their skills," is a critical sentence. Likewise, the point that some problems are best left to a later grade. Developmentally, some students are far from ready for some of the constructs presented in the elementary math curriculum. Having said that, some of the textbooks (now shunned by school boards) were effective at setting up math lessons to cover exploration, problem-solving, consolidation and practice. Now teachers are tasked with creating this content in a cogent manner. The multi-step problem also poses its own challenges, when it comes to EQAO. Students lack resilience and a stick-to-it approach. They are also aware, EQAO does not 'count' toward their grade. Some give up as they just are not invested in the outcome.

Comment: I find some of the issues here rather dubious.

 My wait times so far have been pretty bad for specialists, but next to none for family doctors; however, it is largely family doctors under this scheme who charge fees.

 I don't see how higher fees would change the situation with access to cardiologists, for example, in the first place. Pretty much, every single specialist, with an exception of a psychiatrist, was affiliated with one of the Toronto's hospitals, so a lot of criticisms of "entrepreneurial" culture miss the mark. In most cases, if Ontario wants to change the wait list situation, it should outright hire more doctors in a few specialties. That will be much cheaper than managing dozens of admin employees to manage the dubious fees.

Comment: I'm not "loyal" to Zille, as such – I've never met her, and don't know her. I do tend to stick up for the underdog, though – I don't like to see obvious unfairness.

I agree 100% on De Lille and her pro-development policy. She should never have been given a second term as mayor.

Zille's error was that she tried to rush things. I can understand why – she could see that SA has a limited period in which to rid itself of the ANC, or it will be too late. She wanted the DA to take power as soon as possible, so that SA could be turned back from the precipice. To do that, the DA needed the black vote. To do that, the DA needed (in her mind) a black leader. THAT is where things went wrong. Her choices of possible black leaders for the DA have been abysmal. What we have now is a DA that probably WON'T be able to save SA, because it is rapidly turning into the ANC. Coalition government may still save us, but however we look at it, our future is depressingly uncertain.

Comment: Driverless trains have been around a long time. Even trackless trains following a strip in the road exist (yes, we could have built a train like that with a double decked freeway). I can't see getting rid of attendants when wheelchair/special assistance is required. But I don't foresee traffic relief without fundamental change in how we use autos. Long known in the industry that capacity improvements transportation alternatives are possible but auto congestion relief is problematic. Build new road capacity, it will eventually get plugged up. Perhaps driverless autos can alleviate flow in the future. In the meantime we should have focused on far less costly options like freeway entry lights during peak traffic hours, number of autos at any given household (greatly increased taxes on 2nd, 3rd, etc). Thsee kinds of traffic reduction solutions work without multi billion dollar rails. These are just examples. There are other options.

Comment: Yet the Supremes have said that a law must have a rational basis and those who drafted this one admitted that it did not. If they claimed that it did, then the state could try to show what the rational basis is. I'm not sure how the state could defend it when its arbitrary nature is already admitted. It would be an interesting case.

I know little about the drinking age, but isn't it theoretically something a state can ditch as long as the state is willing to give up federal highway funds? But your point is taken; we pick arbitrary numbers all the time. As long as we pretend that they have a rational basis we get away with it. 

My argument in the age of consent case is that the state's drafting team created a constitutional vulnerability when they admitted that the age was arbitrarily chosen.

Comment: That is a classic false dilemma - a false option logical fallacy.  Vision Zero is not a "political ploy by BEST" nor an "LTD gimmick".  
A third alternative is that the existing system does not provide enough safety for pedestrians. As you have noted, "...bikers and pedestrians blindly trust lines painted on the street or traffic/pedestrian lights."  I would not say they "blindly trust" but expect that a green light, a walk sign and a crosswalk means it is safe to cross. Sure, people still need to look both ways, but your accusation that they have "blind trust" blames the pedestrian when they have the right-of-way.
As far as saying, "Until that changes, we’ll probably hear more tragic news.", it is not a "tragedy" if the system is designed without adequate safety. It is a correctable design error  This is why Vision Zero calls it "collisions", not accidents. 
I get a sense there is an undercurrent of nefarious motivations by govt. and pedestrian are at fault. Are those your beliefs?

Comment: I can see the problem.  It's called boredom.

Due to flight schedules, pilots are expected to wait around for hours at a time in airports until their next flight.  Airports are notoriously uncomfortable places to wait around, with chairs designed to be uncomfortable to sleep in, the lights are always on, constant announcements and your lucky just to find a television playing something other than flight schedules with audio enabled.

Leave the airport and you have to queue up for security searches on your way back in, and if it is an international flight you will have to clear customs in both directions which also takes time and a long time in queue.

For these pilots, a way to kill the time is to hit one of the ubiquitous bars near the gate.  One drink leads to another, which leads to another, as they kill hour after hour waiting around.  Sure they could eat, and they probably do, but in a 6 hour layover there's only so many meals you can have. Give them a place to nap.

Comment: As an avid mountain biker, and at the risk of getting heat from my mountain biking friends, I tend to agree. I wish I could claim mountain bikers ride slow and cautiously down hills, but realistically, they often don't. I've seen it myself - flying by hikers coming down from Indigo Lake and other locations, sometimes scaring them. And if we open the door to bikes, then equestrians won't have a bike-free place to ride (or there will be FAR fewer places). Bikes don't mix well with horses. Also, opening the door to bikes potentially opens the door to other mechanized equipment - maybe even motorized. While each bike doesn't have much impact, there are just so many mountain bikers that they do have an impact on trail quality when there are lots of them. 

 If the issue is Wilderness taking over former mountain bike trails, then that's a discussion against giving the  wilderness designation, not watering down the entry limitations.

I made the choice of consuming a plant based diet; I took nutrition and cooking lessons; I started exercising again on a regular basis because I had energy.  Now - 6 months later I've lost over 40 pounds, blood sugar levels are normal and I feel great.  I've never been hungry.  My motivation was health and now I'm experiencing the benefits of the choices I've made.

Comment: Impressions, expectations, and "hoped fors" don't count when you are dealing with written law. The state offered and gives tax credits. There is no dedicated fund to buy credits. See the Alaska Supreme Court's decision on PFD appropriations to review the anti-dedication provision in Alaska's Constitution. Cash is subject to appropriation. The credits can be held until the person holding them can apply them, and could be sold to a taxpayer that can use them. Granted, a sale to another company would likely be at a discount. We often wish the law says something else, but this law always made cash for credits subject to appropriation. Reread AS 43.55.023, 43.55.025, and 43.55.028 as those sections read prior to this year's amendments.

Comment: U.S. Healthcare does cost more than in other nations.  But, single payer is not the primary reason.  Cost of living and average incomes play major roles.  For example, in the U.S. the average income of an Orthopedic Surgeon is $442,450.  A Canadian Orthopedic Surgeon gets $208,000, less than half.  All other health care workers get less pay.  In fact, all Canadians make less.  That was a central point in a comparison of US and Canadian health care costs conducted by Canada's leading think tank, the Fraser Institute.  The found that after deducting our average health care costs, Americans made $6,000 more, per year, on average, than did Canadians.   Americans pay more for health care simply because we can afford to.  If we got the exact care Canadians get, your out of pocket drug costs would inrease, mental health services would be scarcer and people seeking gender reassignment would often be out in the cold.  Waiting lists are a scandal in Canada.  Is that what we really want?

Comment: lescaine: I'm skeptical of Trump's motives and intentions but one aspect of his appeal, where he calls for 'fair trade' as opposed to 'free trade', seems entirely reasonable and justifiable. I'm not at all a fan of multinational trade deals that create institutions and rules that are independent from the purview of democratic institutions. At least the E.U. attempts to address this with a transnational parliament, although the continuing and predicable attachment to national governments and (mainly ethnic) states undermines the authority of that body. I agree with you that it should be possible to challenge orthodoxies, including globalization, and it's unhealthy to prevent such criticism in democracies, but surely there are good and bad ways to model and implement transnational and global institutions. Unfortunately, in the current iteration of globalization we've seen too much of the pro-corporate bad and not enough of the democratic good.

Comment: I disagree.  That's the usual narrative, but it isn't always the case.  There are great public schools, and also awful ones.  There are great Catholic schools, but also awful ones.  Bullying goes on everywhere -- in any kind of school.  It is a societal problem that no one wants to deal with.  

Because of my own, personal, experience in Catholic schools, I told my husband that -- should we decide to have children -- Catholic or other faith-based schools would not be an option for any reason.  His experience was, however, very different from mine.

The reason many Catholic schools take in non-Catholics is to boost the numbers and ensure they are not closed.  I don't doubt many of the children get a quality education, but (at the end of the day) my tax dollars will be being used to prop up a school the purpose of which is to educate one religious group.  I would personally like to see excellent public schools, and small numbers of faith-based schools serving their communities alone.

Comment: Part of the problem is that a handful of 'battleground' states decide the election each year. Basically, the rest of the states don't matter.  Most of CA is blue so the candidates know that all of CA's EC votes will go to the dem.  The converse is true in Texas.  So no one bothers to visit those states.  The winner-take-all system is the problem.  

What if CA distributed its EC votes proportional to the popular vote in that state.  It would be worth it for the repub candidate to spend time there to try to capture a portion of those votes.  Same for Texas, or Alaska.  This would force the candidates to broaden their message to appeal to a wider range of Americans.

The EC math would still advantage rural states like Alaska, but in a close race it might even be worth it for a candidate to swing through here to pick up a vote or two.  As it is now, we'll never see a candidate because they'll be spending all their time in OH or FL or NC.

Comment: As the author highlights the Australian regulatory framework as one to be emulated, I would also point out that Australian financial advisors have a fiduciary duty to their clients when giving financial advice. How about we emulate that too!  And why doesn't the author recommend that?  (the standard in here is only "suitability" of an investment. That is a lower standard.)  A fiduciary relationship is a legal standard that requires the advisor to put the client interests ahead of his/her own.  For example, several investments might be "suitable" for a given client's risk profile. Putting the client into the one that pays the highest trailer fee would meet the "suitability" requirement, but not a fiduciary standard.

Comment: The cultural conditions that developed in the south were inherently embedded for two hundred years prior to the outbreak of the war.  The war was about slavery, a system of bondage that was present in the north, even during the period of the Civil War.  Slavery was not unique to just the southern states.  Equally important - when the Constitution was drafted everyone at Constitution was afraid to tackle the ugliness of slavery.  The framers kicked the ball down the road at least twenty years thinking that somehow an answer would be forthcoming.  The second major problem with the Constitutional Convention and the men who ratified the Constitution in each of the thirteen states - each state had a different view of the powers of the federal government vis-a-vis state autonomy.  Hamilton, Adams, and Madison (to some degree) argued for a strong central government.  Jefferson, Patrick Henry and Anti-Federalists still believed the central government was subservient to state authority.

Comment: That may be true in a bubble, but we are talking planetary impacts.  I don't expect increased vegetation to necessarily be the norm everywhere.  In the US, growing zones are already marching northward along with the flora and fauna.  Great news if you are looking for an extended growing season.  Not so great for the local occupants, who will wind up moving north as the migrants start modifying the local ecosystem in order to set up housekeeping.   Not necessarily so great for farmers whose business models and crop selections may need modification.  Not so great if the local weather goes off in a different direction in response to the changes in climate inputs that caused the changes in the growing zones.

We don't seem able to think systemically, and that will not help us in the long run.  This article does not address the specifics we are discussing but it illustrates the need to think systemically. 

https://www.lawfareblog.com/nuclear-energy-climate-change-and-security-threats

I initiated the concept, which the JWN proposed to staff, for a community planning process to develop the old Naval Reserve site as medium- and/or high-density, affordable (potentially subsidized) multi-generational, "family-friendly" housing. Staff shot it down. Bonny Bettman and I got City Council to adopt "Opportunity Siting" to support _compatible_ higher-density housing in existing neighborhoods. Staff hijacked it and produced SW-SAZ, which is completely antithetical to OS.

We need competent planners and elected officials to get this right.

-- Paul

There was no material distinction between fluoridation and other established public health measures, such as chlorination of water or the addition of iodine to salt.”

Comment: Perhaps because the courts have ruled that there is a duty to consult and accommodate Aboriginal groups on such matters as a result of the Constitution?

In Canada, the duty to consult and accommodate with Aboriginal peoples arises when the Crown (federal and/or provincial) contemplates actions or decisions that may affect an Aboriginal person's Aboriginal or Treaty rights which are entrenched in our Constitution - you know the supreme law of the land. This duty arises most often in the context of natural resource extraction and transport.

See:
Haida Nation v. British Columbia (Minister of Forests) 2004 SCC 73
Mikisew Cree First Nation v Canada (Minister of Canadian Heritage), 2005 SCC 69
Taku River Tlingit First Nation v British Columbia (Project Assessment Director), 2004 SCC 74, [2004]

And most recently in 2014 in an 8-0 decision the SCOC edged right up to the existence of a veto held by Aboriginal groups affected in Tsilhqot'in Nation v British Columbia 2014 SCC 44

Comment: "Rape is an outrage that cannot be tolerated in a civilized society." ~ Camille Paglia

Does that statement, by implication, mean that other forms of assault are not an outrage?

In my view, rape and other forms of sexual assault mustn't be viewed in a fundamentally different manner than other assaults. ALL assaults are a violation of an individual's physical and emotional well-being. For example, an unwanted slap on a woman's behind is a sexual assault. Is that a worse offence than slapping a man on the face? Which hurts more? Which is more demeaning?

Women are often victims of sexual assault. Feminists have drawn attention to that problem by claiming that it's a particularly pernicious form of assault. In doing so they've taken attention away from physical assault, which men experience at far higher rates than women.

The problem won't be fixed one gender at a time. No form of assault against anyone is acceptable, and all forms of assault must be condemned equally.

Comment: No, angelo, you're wrong.  I'm talking about the number of oil tankers used for import of crude oil -- which was the false claim you made in your original post.

Your fact sheet is referring to oil tankers importing and exporting crude oil plus all the small tankers distributing REFINED products.  Nobody in BC is taking issue with the 1200 or so tanker trips in coastal BC importing and distributing refined fuels.  And of course there are thousands of tanker trips delivering refined products in or from Atlantic Canada because we refine about 6 times more oil than BC does -- around 420,000 bbl/day -- and export most of it to the US.

As for oil export, Newfoundland has 4 small ships that collect oil from the offshore with a combined capacity of 1 M bbl, ie, less than one ship per day takes oil to Wiffen Head, which can accommodate tankers up to Aframax size, ie,around 750,000 bbl, so about 2 or 3 oil tankers a week leave Newfoundland to ship crude oil to Irving and outside of Canada.

Comment: I'm not sure of the amount, but initially 100% of the mining royalties went to the general fund. They never imagined it would create such an excess, they had only hoped it would reduce the state income tax. 2 or 3 years they eliminated the income tax, created the pf were 50% of resource royalties went into gf the rest into the pf where the pfd would be paid off the interest to the people, as the minerals are by law the people's. About 8 years ago the pfd was recalculated to be a 5 yr average payout. During the palin administration, she distributed an additional 2k out of the general fund(the reserve), because the economy was stagnant and the state was setting on about 50 billion dollars in the reserve with 100+ $ a barrel oil coming in. Btw last calculation I heard on the reserve, it was over 12 billion or 3 to 4 year reserve with zero income. Most states reserves are 10 to 15 day reserve, we have the highest reserve in the US by years.

Comment: A little history:

W. A. C. Bennett was elected in 1952, 1953, 1956, 1960, 1963, 1966 and 1969.  Speaks to the satisfaction of the electorate with a free-enterprise government, doesn’t it?

Dave Barrett’s NDP were in office just over 3 years, Sept. 1972 to Dec. 1975.  Tossed after one term.

Social Credit ran the province from December 1975 till November 1991. Again, free enterprise satisfied the electorate over the long term.

The NDP were elected in 1991.  In 2001 they were reduced to two seats.  Speaks volumes to the satisfaction of the public after actually enduring the NDP again, doesn’t it?

BC Liberal party has governed 2001 to present.  Under the Liberals, BC now enjoys the most robust economy in Canada, the lowest unemployment rate, and some of the highest scholastic achievements in the developed world.

And people would actually consider trading in a legacy of free enterprise success for socialism - again?  
Didn’t work before . . . why believe it now?

Comment: Yeah... you failed to mention the apparent fact that Home Capital Group is actually a victim of  bad mortgage brokers that were racking up fat commissions for themselves while misrepresenting borrower qualifications. The iffy loans actually represent only 8 % of HCG's mortgage portfolio, so it was an easily resolved problem, given HCG's balance sheet and a rising real estate market.

THE QUESTION, now, is whether HCG actually fullfilled its disclosure obligations to investors in a timely manner. The OSC believes they did not, as there was a six month period between discovery of the problem, and full disclosure. HCG initially, and reasonably, mounted an internal investigation to understand the scope of the problem, in order to effectively resolve it.
The question here is, I think, is a company required to publicly disclose  every problem BEFORE the company itself knows whether the issue is material to results?

Comment: 12345Bill
There is a risk, several risks with a federal government pension plan. It should be understood that a pension is part of the pay package. It is not a gift. Federal Treasury Board says that total compensation in the public sector must equal total compensation in the private sector for similar jobs. Our military pension actuarial cost was 25.02% of salary. The public service 16.2%.That is money we did not get.

The gov't can attack the pension at any time. It did so in the mid 1980s, reducing indexing for two years.

The pensions are based on the average salary in the last 5 years of employment. For example 30 years work, a 60% pension The purchasing power of the pension is affected by inflation during the salary averaging years. . The purchasing power of people retiring this year with 60% pensions would be about 56% of average purchasing power in the 5 years. 1981 retirees, 44%.

I understand from Treasury Board that this same method of averaging applies to all DB pensions

Plyer vs. Doe (1982)
Zadvydas vs. Davis (2001)

Comment: The problem for would-be schismatics is that they need a lot of followers or they look pretty silly. Cardinal Burke may be a hot topic of conversation on this board, but your average Catholic in the pew has never heard of the guy. And even if they had, he'd need a sexier cause than this to get them fired up.

Marcel Lefebvre won followers because a lot of people still felt strongly about the Latin Mass. But you're not going to find too many people jazzed enough about their divorced neighbor getting to receive Communion that they'd be willing to throw in with a renegade cardinal.

Let's face it. Shifts in pastoral practice are not the stuff schisms are made of.

Comment: Ontario Provincial politics over the next 2 years may well diminish Federal Liberal prospects to the advantage of both the Conservatives & NDP provided that 

(a) the Ontario Conservatives don't campaign (and don't govern) too far to the hard right in tone and substance, and 

(b) the Ontario NDP can present a convincing fresh progressive agenda and leadership to replace a stumbling Ontario Liberal Party.

The spill-over effect of Provincial political trends and developments has historically been a major (if under-reported and appreciated) factor in Federal politics.  Given the size of Ontario, the growing demand for a new beginning in place of Ontario's Liberal Government and the increased polarization of the Ontario electorate (all of which to be crystallized and highlighted by the upcoming Ontario election) is bound to have its impact on the Federal political scene in the run-up to the next Federal General Election.
